legal_basis: Notice is given under section 1 of the Statistics of Trade Act 1947.
title: Annual Business Survey

description.text: If the company details or structure have changed contact us on {telephone_number_link} or email {email_link}

list: You have been selected to complete the Annual Business Survey (ABS).
This survey is a key resource for understanding the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.

The information you supply helps to measure the UK economy and is used by the government to determine economic policy. The ABS also influences decisions on company and personal taxation and on interest rates.
You cannot appeal your selection. Your business was selected to give us a comprehensive view of the UK economy.
You still need to complete this survey even if it does not seem relevant. All returns are important as it helps us produce better statistics.
We will treat your data securely and confidentially.
View the latest publication from this survey (this link opens in a new tab)

contents.description: View the questions before you start the survey (this link opens in a new tab)
This questionnaire is divided into sections, which ask for information about:
This section asks about the period for which your business will be reporting.
Your return period should cover the calendar year 2022. If no figures are available for that period, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.
This section asks for information regarding your business's income. This includes questions about total turnover and environmental turnover.
This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.
This includes:

list: employment costs
costs of energy, goods, materials, and services
value of grants and donations paid out
depreciation of capital assets
rates, duties, levies, and taxes paid to the government

contents.description: This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of goods.
This section asks for information regarding your business's research and development.

list: The statistics produced help to improve the overall quality of National Accounts and the measurement of Gross Domestic Product (this link opens in a new tab).

In addition to the National Accounts, the ABS is also used by the Scottish Government and Welsh Government in the compilation of both regional country specific Input and Output tables and Indices of Production.
It also provides a major contribution to the Blue Book, which is produced annually by our National Accounts Team and used to inform HM Treasury in managing economic policy.

sections.title: How to complete and reporting period

content.title: How to complete and reporting period

contents.description: The ABS collects information to better understand the structure, conduct and performance of businesses across the UK.
Please read the following information before starting the survey.

list: Questions in this survey ask for figures either for GB or the UK. Instructions will be provided for each question to know which figures to provide.

Questions that ask for UK data should relate to business activity in England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland, but exclude the Channel Islands and Isle of Man. For GB data, exclude Northern Ireland.
You can provide informed estimates if actual figures are not available.
Please round your figures to the nearest £1,000.
You can save a copy of your answers at the end of this questionnaire using the ‘Download as PDF’ button.
Refer to additional guidance accompanying each question for more information.

contents.description: View the website for more information and guidance (this link opens in a new tab)

contents.title: What activity to include in this survey

contents.description: Any activity outside the UK lasting for more than one year should be excluded from this questionnaire, except all installation activities outside the UK, which should be included regardless of the length of period of the work carried out.

Any work done in connection with overseas contracts where employees travel abroad regularly for short periods should be included and any overseas activity which is deemed to be capital expenditure in that country should be excluded.

description.text: You will be asked to report for {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}. If you are unable to provide figures for this period, you will have the option to choose your own dates.

title.text: Are you able to report for the calendar year {ref_p_start_date} to {ref_p_end_date}?

description: Your return should relate to the calendar year 2022.

contents.description: Traded for part of the year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'
Cannot report for this calendar year?
Please select 'No, I need to report for a different period'

options.label: Yes, I can report for this period
options.value: Yes, I can report for this period

options.label: No, I need to report for a different period
options.value: No, I need to report for a different period

in: Yes, I can report for this period

question.title: What dates will you be reporting for?
description: If figures are not available for the calendar year 2022, your return should relate to a business year that ends between 6 April 2022 and 5 April 2023.

contents.description: Did your business only trade for part of the year?
Please provide figures for the period in which you were trading.
Has your business commenced trading during 2022?
Your return should cover the period from the commencement of your business until 31 December 2022 or, alternatively, any date up to 5 April 2023.
Has your business ceased trading during 2022?
Your return should cover the period 1 January 2022 to the date you ceased to trade or, alternatively, from the beginning of your last business year up to the cessation date.

in: Yes, I can report for this period

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's income. This includes questions about total turnover and environmental turnover.
This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s total turnover?

description: Report GB figures. An informed estimate is acceptable. Refer to the 'additional guidance' for more information.

contents.description: Include:

list: progress payments on work in progress on long-term contracts
management fees
inter group charges

contents.description: Exclude:

list: VAT
donations and general funding

contents.description: This refers to the total amount receivable in respect of invoices raised during the period of the return, for the sale of goods and services. Figures should be given gross of indirect taxes, duties and levies (except VAT) invoiced to the customer.

answers.label: Total turnover
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: all sales of goods, except fixed capital assets, including exports and goods purchased and resold without processing

provision of goods and/or services to other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if sold to an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, please value them at transfer cost
work done on customers’ materials including the value of any additional materials added
income from construction activity, even if subcontracted
income from all industrial and non-industrial services rendered
income derived from the renting of property
amounts received for the right to use patents, trademarks, and copyrights
receipts from government for goods and services supplied free, or at a subsidised rate, under the National Health Service and similar public services
transport, insurance and packaging charges, less amounts for returnable containers, invoiced by your business, even if invoiced separately
income from subcontracted activities

for commission work, where you do not hold title to goods sold, the commission or fee is to be included but not the full transaction price. Also to be included here are costs incurred and passed on to the customer
the value of second-hand goods taken in part exchange, such second-hand goods should also be recorded as purchases
service charges for credit provided but not interest charges
the value of vouchers, tokens, and coupons used by customers as a means of payment, but not the sale of such vouchers to customers
royalty payments received

contents.description: Exclude:

list: output for own final use
income recorded as extraordinary income in your accounts
the sale of vehicles previously treated as capital assets during the period
interest payments received and other similar income
amounts received from the sale of fixed capital assets
amounts received from the sale of patents, trademarks, and copyrights
grants from any source
subsidies from UK public authorities and the European Union (EU)
value of insurance claims received
income derived from the renting of land if recorded separately within your accounts
income recorded as 'Other Operating Income' in your accounts
all trade, cash or other discounts and rebates, record turnover net of these
sales by other businesses operating on your premises as well as any commission received on such sales
dividends received
the full value of any transfer fees received

title.text: You have reported your business's total turnover for the period {from} to {to} to be {total_turnover}. Is this correct?

options.label: No, I need to change this
options.value: No, I need to change this

==: No, I need to change this

question.title: For the reporting period, what was the total of your business's other income?
description: Report GB figures. An informed estimate is acceptable.

contents.description: Include:

list: fundraising
grants received from public bodies, other charitable organisations, for example, European, Local Education Authority and government grants or funding
all gifts of cash and other financial assets received, for example, the value of stocks and shares, marketable debt instruments and foreign currency as valued at the time when taken into your books
income received from the sale of tangible assets received as gifts, for example, land and works of art
proceeds of raffles, lotteries, jumble sales, sponsored events, door to door and street collections
grants and donations made specifically for the financing of capital expenditure and included in the Income and Expenditure Account
legacies
investment income

contents.description: Exclude:

list: interest and dividends

contents.description: This refers to the value of grants, donations, legacies, investment income and general funding received.

answers.label: Total of other income
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

question.title: Does your business produce goods or services that protect the environment?

contents.description: Include:
Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are produced by your business. For example:

list: production or installation of solar panels
waste collection, treatment and disposal services
environmental consultancy and training services

contents.description: Exclude:
Goods and/or services that protect the environment that are used by your business. For example:

list: the use of energy saving light bulbs
the consumption of recycled materials

title.text: Of {total_turnover}, approximately what percentage related to the production of environmental goods or services?

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's expenditure.
This includes:

list: employment costs
costs of energy, goods, materials, and services
value of grants and donations paid out
depreciation of capital assets
rates, duties, levies, and taxes paid to the government

contents.description: This section requires figures for business activity within GB. Exclude Northern Ireland business activity.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s expenditure on employment costs?

description:
Report GB figures.

Wages and salaries are defined as the total compensation in cash or in-kind payable to all employees. State the amount paid before deductions but less any amounts for which you are reimbursed from government sources.

contents.description: Include:

list: accrued holiday pay
all overtime payments, bonuses, commissions

the cost to the employer of all expenses and benefits in-kind. These include assets transferred to employees such as cars, property, goods or other assets. Payments made on behalf of employees such as mileage allowances and fuel payments, unless the payments are in respect of travelling expenses. Subsidies to staff canteens, sports club membership, nurseries, playschemes and health insurance
employment costs paid to workers employed by the UK company and workers employed who are based overseas. These costs should only reflect the installation services activity carried out outside the UK
payments into pension funds providing retirement or death benefits for employees, including former employees or their dependents
any 'signing on' fees paid to employees
payments to welfare schemes

contents.description: Exclude:

list: payments to working proprietors, partners, and executive directors not in receipt of a regular salary, fee or commission
amounts paid to subcontractors
travelling and subsistence expenses
payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
top up of pension funds or withdrawals from pension funds
rebates received from National Insurance Redundancy Fund
contributions by employers for their own personal pension schemes
employees' National Insurance contributions

contents.description: An employee is anyone aged 16 or over that your organisation pays directly from its payroll(s), in return for carrying out a full-time or part-time job or being on a training scheme.
Include:

list: all workers such as permanent, temporary, casual and seasonal workers, paid directly from this business's payroll(s)
those temporarily absent but still being paid, for example on parental leave, on holiday or on sick

contents.description: Exclude:

list: former employees only receiving a pension
self-employed workers
subcontractors

answers.label: Total expenditure on employment costs
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on energy, goods, materials and services?
description:
Report GB figures.

State the net cost of purchases made during the period of this return whether or not they were used or resold during that period.

contents.description: Include:

list: raw materials
non-deductible VAT
import and excise duties
management fees
inter group charges

contents.description: Exclude:

list: employment costs
all interest payments
amounts charged to capital account
capitalised building repairs
deductible VAT

answers.label: Total expenditure on energy, materials, goods and services
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: all fuel costs purchased for use in the running of your business. For example, electricity, gas, oil, coal, coke, petrol and diesel
purchases of water used in the running of your business, including water extraction charges
sewerage charges and other costs of effluent and waste disposal
total fees and commissions payable
other goods and materials such as machine spares, packaging materials, and office materials charged to you. For example, stationery and consumables
the cost of goods and materials purchased for use in the installation, repair or maintenance of customers’ goods
any goods and materials for resale without further processing such as merchanted goods, goods purchased and resold without modification
any goods bought on a 'sale or return' basis which were subsequently sold but exclude the cost of those returned unsold
payments for hiring, leasing, or renting, plant machinery and vehicles, if acquired under operational leases, but not if purchased under hire purchase or finance leasing arrangements
commercial insurance premiums paid
road transport services purchased for own staff use, for example, buses and taxis
purchases of computer and related services, including consultancy charges on computer software and hardware and the cost of repair, maintenance and installation of office and computing machinery
purchases of advertising and marketing services not carried out by your own staff
payments to employment agencies for the services of agency staff
labour recruitment administration costs
amounts, except those charged to the capital account, payable to others for the services of accountants, auditors, agents, solicitors and surveyors
amounts payable to other organisations and self-employed persons, for example, for labour they have supplied
amounts payable for the right to use patents, trademarks, copyrights, manufacturing rights and technical know-how
amounts payable to other organisations for technical research and studies
amounts payable for sea, air, and rail freight on goods transported
building materials for own use
building repairs, maintenance, and contract cleaning services
payments to other businesses within the same group, for example, service companies
bank charges excluding interest payments
rent paid on buildings or dwellings
amounts paid for licensing, inspection and monitoring
staff travel
travelling and subsistence expenses for individual claims
congestion charges including related fines and penalties
amounts payable for printing services provided
amounts payable for repairs, installation, and maintenance of plant, machinery and vehicles
royalty payments
net payments to trade associations and similar bodies

transfer of goods to your business from other parts of your company or organisation which are not covered by this return. These should be valued as if purchased from an independent customer. If you are unable to supply figures on this basis, value them at transfer cost
the cost of any materials you have supplied for work done by you as a subcontractor
post and telecommunications costs
rental of telephone headsets and modems
purchase of telephone headsets and modems
payments to sub-contractors
payments to homeworkers on piecework rates
exam costs and amounts payable for training packages
payments made to claimants
insurance costs which are passed on to the customer
any other goods or services purchased

contents.description: Exclude:

list: bad debts including future provisions
any allowances for depreciation, amortisation, or obsolescence including future provisions
hire purchase repayments
finance leasing payments
fines and penalties except those related to congestion charges
amounts charged to capital account including computer hardware, software and programs written by a third party to be used for more than one year
national non-domestic business rates
the full value of any transfer fees paid out
amounts payable for repairs and maintenance of household and domestic equipment
Mortgage Interest and Mortgage Loan Payments
rent payments on land

question.title: For the reporting period, what was the value of grants and donations paid out to persons, charitable organisations and other organisations?

contents.description: Include all gifts of cash and other financial assets

answers.label: Total value of grants and donations paid
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's depreciation of capital assets?
description:
Report GB figures.

Accounting methods should be acceptable under the FRS15 Tangible Fixed Assets as from March 2021.

definitions.title: What we mean by 'depreciation of capital assets'

contents.description: This refers to the measure of the wearing out, consumption or other reduction in the useful economic life of a fixed asset, whether arising from use, effluxion of time or obsolescence through technology or market changes.

answers.label: Depreciation of capital assets
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government?
description:
Report GB figures.

You should only include the value for the rates, duties, levies and taxes listed below if your business paid these directly to government, statutory bodies or regulators. Do not include these taxes if they were paid as part of your purchase of goods, materials and services.

contents.description: Include:

list: national non-domestic business rates
vehicle excise duty, also known as road, car or vehicle tax

the Climate Change Levy (CCL), introduced in April 2001, is charged on industrial and commercial use of various forms of energy. For example, primary and secondary fuel for lighting, heating, motive power, and power for appliances

contents.description: Exclude:

list: VAT
tax already included in the purchase of goods, materials and services
Corporation Tax
Income Tax
Capital Gains Tax
any agreed reductions on the Climate Change Levy

answers.label: Expenditure on rates, duties, levies and taxes paid to the government
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: Include:

list: excise duties when paid directly to government by your business. For example, on alcohol, tobacco and hydrocarbon oil duty
any business rates or formula rates paid to local authorities or Department of Communities and Local Government (DCLG). Formula rates paid to DCLG applies to Great Britain only
stamp duties. Brokers only - exclude stamp duties paid on the purchase of shares on behalf of clients
export levies, for example, under the EU's Common Agricultural Policy

regulator fees including any statutory amounts paid to: Environment Agency (EA), Office of Gas and Electricity Markets (OFGEM), Office of Water Service Regulation (OFWAT) in England and Wales and the Scottish Water and Sewerage Customers Council (SWSCC) in Scotland, Office of Communications (OFCOM) and Office of Rail and Road (ORR)
Consumer and Credit Act fees
franchise payments to government, for example, rail franchise premia
EU Emissions Trading System
CRC Energy Efficient Scheme, formerly known as Carbon Reduction Commitment
Renewable Energy Obligations
sugar levy
levies paid to government levy-funded bodies, for example, Financial Services Compensation Scheme, Agriculture & Horticulture Development Board and Sea Fish Industry Authority
Vehicle Registration Tax paid upon registering a new or imported vehicle for the first time

contents.description: Exclude:

list: water rates and sewerage charges
council tax payable via local authorities in respect of your rented property
operators' licences
net payments to trade associations and similar bodies
Inheritance Tax
Air Passenger Duty
Landfill Tax
Insurance Premium Tax
Lottery Duty
stamp duties paid on the purchases of shares by brokers on behalf of their clients
fees and other licences, for example, passports, television, boating and fishing
rent payments on land

contents.description: This section asks you to provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.
Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s total value of capital assets acquired and disposed of?

description:
Report UK figures.

Provide the total value of acquisitions and proceeds from the disposal of capital assets that are used repeatedly to facilitate production, or provide services, for more than one year.

Information requested may not always be found on a register of capital assets, and should include all assets of any value, even if this is below your Asset Register threshold.

contents.description: Include:

list: assets within the UK
non-deductible VAT
delivery, installation and decommissioning costs
transfer costs, professional charges, contracts and fees, for example, surveyors' fees, stamp duty, taxes and legal costs. Include costs invoiced to you separately
expenditure on replacing assets destroyed in circumstances, for example, fire, which have given rise to a successful insurance claim
expenditure on assets acquired for hiring, renting and other leasing purposes, but not finance leasing
capital expenditure at any site belonging to the business where operations have not yet begun
grants and allowances from government sources, statutory bodies or local authorities that have been used to acquire or create assets used in production
finance relating to Public Private Partnership or Private Finance Initiative that has been used to acquire assets
progress payments or deposits covering long-term contracts acquiring fixed assets
all work of a capital nature carried out by your own staff, including labour costs and the cost of purchases consumed in the work

contents.description: Exclude:

list: assets outside the UK
deductible VAT
current repair and maintenance costs
costs of ongoing management of computer software and databases
performance related fees paid to or by the club, and fees paid to agents for player transfers
revaluations of assets, for example, depreciation, amortisation, and impairment charges
interest and instalment payments under finance leasing arrangements
capital expenditure on assets for use outside the UK, except ships and aircraft
the proceeds from an insurance claim against the loss of fixed assets

contents.description: Include:

list: land and land improvements or preparation, for own use
other natural resources and non-produced assets, for example, subsoil assets, crude oil, coal, water abstraction
non-produced assets, for example, goodwill, patents, licences, concessions, contracts, trade dress, mastheads, domain names, collective and certification marks
existing buildings and structures for own use or where you are responsible for non-dwelling maintenance
major refurbishment, newly built and construction work for own use
construction of structures such as oil wells, platforms, mines, pipes, power lines, transport infrastructure, wind farms, turbines, and steel frameworks

transport assets and equipment, for example, new and used vehicles, special purpose vehicles, trailers, ships, boats, aircraft and railway rolling stock, motorcycles, bicycles, parts, accessories, and major repairs
computers and hardware devices, for example, printers, servers, monitors, keyboards, and terminals
computer software programs and databases
telecommunication equipment, for example, phones, fax machines, switchboards, transmitters, CCTV equipment, TV cameras, and burglar or fire alarms
electrical equipment and electronic appliances
furniture and office equipment
small tools
general and special purpose equipment
fabricated products, for example, textile, leather, plastic, and metal products
intellectual property assets, for example, recordings, films and performances, manuscripts and publications, plans, instructions, and designs
the purchase costs and disposal proceeds of fixed assets, together with any other amounts treated as capital items for taxation purposes
the total capital value of assets that have been bought on hire purchase in the period covered by this survey
assets acquired under finance lease transfers where you, the lessee, are responsible for and leasing repairs and maintenance
assets owned by the business but leased to another business under an operating lease where you, the lessor, are responsible for repairs and maintenance

contents.description: Exclude:

list: assets acquired in taking over an existing business or sold as part of a going concern
assets of a capital nature acquired for resale rather than for use within business, for example, stocks of vehicles held by motor traders
assets like TV adverts or copyrights
assets leased to another business under finance lease, such as repair and maintenance are carried out by the other business known as the lessee
assets acquired under an operating lease, such as responsibility for repair and maintenance is borne by the owner, or lessor, of the asset
asset transfers between companies owned by the same enterprise, except where the asset value is considered to be a 'new' acquisition or disposal within the company accounts
software licences of up to a year
structures that are used primarily as residences or dwellings
utilities such as gas, electricity, and water
research and development
works of art, for example, paintings and sculptures, even if acquired or disposed of by dealers, galleries, or museums

answers.label: Total value of capital assets from acquisitions
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

answers.label: Total value of capital assets from disposals
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of services. This includes income and expenditure.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, what was {ru_name}'s income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK?

description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident and hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.

contents.description: Include:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside of the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK
management fees

contents.description: Exclude:

list: dividend or interest payments
transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
repairs other than for construction equipment and computers
transactions in financial assets or liabilities
salaries of staff seconded abroad if their absence is for more than one year
business travel services such as accommodation and meals whilst abroad
trade in goods

definitions.title: Examples of services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations

list: repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance or any other repairs
the hiring out of plant, machinery and other goods such as operational leasing
advertising and commission as an agent, excluding the value of imports or exports of goods

answers.label: Total income from services provided to individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

question.title: For the reporting period, what was your business's expenditure on services provided by individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?
description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident and hence transactions in services with these entities should be regarded as international trade in services.

contents.description: Include:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK
merchanting profits and losses on goods bought and sold abroad without entering the UK
management fees

contents.description: Exclude:

list: dividend or interest payments
transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK
repairs other than for construction equipment and computers
transactions in financial assets or liabilities
salaries of staff seconded abroad if their absence is for more than one year
business travel services such as accommodation and meals whilst abroad
trade in goods

definitions.title: Examples of services provided by individuals, enterprises or other organisations

list: repair of construction equipment and computers, but not maintenance or any other repairs
the hiring out of plant, machinery and other goods such as operational leasing
advertising and commission as an agent, excluding the value of imports or exports of goods

answers.label: Total expenditure on services provided by individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK
answers.description: Enter a value to the nearest £thousand (e.g. 56,000). Do not enter ‘56’ for £56,000.

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's international exports and imports of goods.
This section requires figures for business activity within the UK.

title.text: For the period {from} to {to}, did {ru_name} export goods to individuals, enterprises, or other organisations based outside the UK?

description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident and hence transactions in goods with these entities should be regarded as international trade in goods.

contents.description: Include:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK

contents.description: Exclude:

list: trade in services
transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK

contents.description: Goods are specific, tangible commodities.

list: raw materials
semi or finished manufactured goods
food, beverages and tobacco
basic materials
oil and other fuel

question.title: For the reporting period, did your business import goods from individuals, enterprises or other organisations based outside the UK?
description:
The UK is defined as England, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland. It does not include the Channel Islands or the Isle of Man.

A subsidiary or parent of your company situated in another country is regarded as an international resident and hence transactions in goods with these entities should be regarded as international trade in goods.

contents.description: Include:

list: transactions with branches or subsidiaries of UK businesses that are located outside the UK
transactions with a subsidiary or parent of your company located outside the UK

contents.description: Exclude:

list: trade in services
transactions with branches or subsidiaries of foreign businesses that are located within the UK

contents.description: Goods are specific, tangible commodities.

list: raw materials
semi or finished manufactured goods
food, beverages and tobacco
basic materials
oil and other fuel

contents.description: This section asks for information regarding your business's research and development.
This section requires answers based on business activity within the UK.
Research and Development covers three types of activity:

list: basic research
applied research
experimental development

contents.description: R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - To be aimed at new findings
Creative - To be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - To be uncertain about the final outcome
Systematic - To be planned and budgeted
Transferable or reproducible - To lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

title.text: Did {ru_name} carry out any in-house Research and Development for the period {from} to {to}, or intend to do so in the next reporting period?

description: Base your answer on business activity within the UK.

definitions.title: What we mean by 'Research and Development'

contents.description: Research and Development covers three types of activity:

list: basic research
applied research
experimental development

contents.description: R&D comprises creative and systematic work undertaken in order to increase the stock of knowledge, and in order to devise new applications of available knowledge. R&D activity must have elements of all of these five criteria:
Novel - To be aimed at new findings
Creative - To be based on original, not obvious, concepts and hypotheses
Uncertain - To be uncertain about the final outcome
Systematic - To be planned and budgeted
Transferable or reproducible - To lead to results that could possibly be reproduced

question.title: Please provide any further details that will help us understand your figures and tell an industry story
description:
Explain any changes in your figures from your previous return, if applicable. If you provide comments, we are less likely to contact you with data queries.

Make sure you continue to the next page and select 'submit answers' at the bottom.

contents.description: Please include details of:

list: any zero figures

contents.description: Any significant impacts upon your data resulting from changes to your business. For example:

list: changes to your business structure
type of activity undertaken

contents.description: Changes in the accounting approaches you have taken. For example:

list: change of accounting standard such as IFRS
regulatory changes

contents.description: Learn more about how we use this data (this tab opens in a new tab)

submission.title: Check your answers and submit
submission.warning: You must submit this survey to complete it
submission.guidance: You will have the opportunity to view, save or print a copy of your answers after submitting this survey.
